message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms have been present for more than 2 years, which is characteristic of persistent depressive disorder. The patient does not exhibit any manic or hypomanic episodes, ruling out bipolar disorder. Schizoaffective disorder involves psychotic symptoms, which are not described in this case. Major depressive disorder usually lasts for 6-8 months, but the patient’s symptoms have been present for over 2 years.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been experiencing symptoms of depression for 2-3 years, with feelings of guilt and loss of appetite being present for the past month. This suggests Persistent depressive disorder, which is characterized by a chronic and persistent depressed mood. Major depressive disorder is characterized by more severe and episodic symptoms, while Bipolar disorder and Schizoaffective disorder have additional symptoms such as manic or psychotic episodes. The patient's history of a previous pregnancy loss may also contribute to the development of Persistent depressive disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including persistent sadness over a prolonged period of time, difficulty sleeping and concentrating, and loss of appetite suggest persistent depressive disorder. Major depressive disorder also has similar symptoms, but it is typically characterized by episodic depression lasting at least 2 weeks. Bipolar disorder involves episodes of both depression and mania or hypomania, and schizoaffective disorder involves a combination of psychotic symptoms and mood episodes. None of these diagnoses fit the patient's presentation as well as persistent depressive disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been experiencing symptoms of sadness, loss of appetite, and difficulty concentrating for over 2 years, which suggests persistent depressive disorder. The patient does not exhibit any manic or hypomanic episodes, which rules out bipolar disorder. The patient does not exhibit any psychotic symptoms, which rules out schizoaffective disorder. However, the possibility of major depressive disorder is also present as the patient is experiencing more difficulty coping in the past month.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient describes feeling sad for 2-3 years, which suggests Persistent Depressive Disorder (PDD). The symptoms of guilt, difficulty sleeping, and loss of appetite also support this diagnosis. Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) is characterized by a more intense and shorter duration of symptoms. Bipolar disorder involves manic or hypomanic episodes, which the patient does not describe. Schizoaffective disorder involves a combination of schizophrenia symptoms and mood disorder symptoms, which the patient does not mention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been experiencing symptoms of depression for a prolonged period of time, which suggests Persistent depressive disorder. Major depressive disorder can also be considered, but typically requires an episode lasting 2 weeks or more. Bipolar disorder and Schizoaffective disorder are less likely, as the patient does not exhibit symptoms of mania or psychosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms have been present for at least 2-3 years, suggesting a chronic course of depression, which is characteristic of Persistent depressive disorder. Major depressive disorder can also present with similar symptoms but is usually more episodic rather than chronic. Bipolar disorder and Schizoaffective disorder are less likely given the absence of manic or psychotic symptoms in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been feeling sad for 2-3 years, indicating a chronic mood disturbance. Persistent depressive disorder is characterized by a depressed mood that lasts for at least two years. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping and concentrating, which are common symptoms of this disorder. The guilt over the previous pregnancy, loss of appetite, and lack of interest in having another child are also consistent with persistent depressive disorder. Major depressive disorder would require a more acute onset of symptoms, while bipolar disorder involves cycles of depressed and manic episodes. Schizoaffective disorder involves a combination of mood and psychotic symptoms, which are not present in this patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been experiencing symptoms of depression for more than 2 years, which points towards Persistent depressive disorder (previously known as dysthymia). There is no mention of manic or hypomanic episodes, ruling out Bipolar disorder. Schizophrenia-like symptoms are also not mentioned, ruling out Schizoaffective disorder. Major depressive disorder is a possibility, but the chronicity of the symptoms and the long duration of the patient's illness suggest Persistent depressive disorder as a more likely diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of sadness, difficulty sleeping, and difficulty concentrating suggest depression. The fact that she has felt this way for 3 years and has not had a single day without these symptoms suggests Persistent depressive disorder. Major depressive disorder is typically characterized by episodes of depression lasting at least 2 weeks, whereas bipolar disorder is characterized by episodes of both depression and manic or hypomanic episodes. Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by a combination of symptoms of schizophrenia and mood disorder, which is not consistent with this patient’s symptoms.
